threads.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
In modern controllers natural resting position of index finger is on top of triggers.
So for retro consoles without triggers it makes more sense to map shoulder buttons to triggers.
For PS1/PS2/Ps3 most of the time it makes more sense to swap L1,R1 with L2,R2 given triggers are the main buttons right now unlike in the past. Button prompts do get confusing.
Also there is no travel distance with triggers as our fingers act instantaneous and given you are mapping a digital button to an analog button it would get activated as soon as you press.
There's a reason Nintendo is using triggers even digital buttons. Its comfy.

Do you prefer shoulder buttons or triggers for shoulder buttons?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: This really isn't /vr/, but ironically I despise trigger buttons for gun fire action because it adds nothing to a binary input other than unnecessarily required force. But it is rather useful for something like car Acceleration where fine tuned analog input actually adds something to the equation.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
one of the best aspects of LA is the density of gameplay options at any moment. You're never more than a couple seconds away from participating in its World.

While Kanto is more spread out with a sense of travel, there is more packed into Koholints various screens. It takes a few seconds to move across one screen, on which there is always something to cut, fight, blow-up, talk to, read, check or otherwise.

The speed at which you can execute on your cognitive apprehension of the World is part of what makes it so playable. It totally makes the most of its condensed map.

In conjunction with the speed of its gameplay, the metroidvania-esque gated-ness of the map setup facilitates a kind of dance as you encounter pockets of the map in a recurring fashion, sometimes with additional moves to bring to bare on the obstacles. In this way many of the map screens evolve into having secondary function as you progress through the game.

I've often thought the size of Link in proportion to his speed and relative map size is a particular boon for LA. Perhaps ALBW comes close, but it's been years since I played that and I rushed it. I think a 3d Zelda at some point should learn from LA's speedy, brisk pace and interactive gaminess. The Mario series has toyed around with merging properties of the 2d and 3d entries, and I think there's a way in which Zelda could do it also - without it being merely a campy toybox-like experience. Even LA transcends its face-level childishness and gets to some kind of esoteric meaning that anyone who really loves the game will be familiar with.

last_replies.com:
>>9449870
I know at least 1 anon is going to jump at me for saying this, but I think the reason is because that "final form" of Dracula in Castlevania 1 isn't Dracula, but a different monster called Curse of Man.
When you give Dracula the last hit in CV1, you can see his head flying off, and his body parts flying in different directions, then immediately, Curse of Man appears. Simon beats the monster, but gets cursed - hence why in Simon's Quest he has to uncurse himself by, you guessed it, finding Dracula's different body parts in different places.
IV is like a "good ending" version of Castlevania 1, where Simon effectively vanquishes Dracula for good and you see him dying to the day light, burning out. No curse for Simon, and I think Gaibon is like a mini-version of Curse of Man, at least it sure looks like it.
People still discuss about this because the source of the lore is not very clear, although it's said to come from Akamatsu, the Castlevania creator who has disappeared from the public eye, and only 1 japanese guy who worked with him talked about this in recent years. But to me, it makes sense. Also the IV team being aware of this lore because the IV team is the only one that was in direct contact with Akamatsu (III and IV being developed around the same time, and Akamatsu giving personal advice to the IV team). After CV III, Akamatsu's team dissolved. Games like Rondo or Chronicles just took Curse of Man as the "dracula final form" that everybody knows about.

>I wanted to use the secret map exits and MAPINFO fuckery to create a mini-WAD that had multiple routes through it.
IIRC Darkmoon did something similar, though that was more of a conscious choice between next maps rather than a skill-based differentiation. It's an interesting way of giving a form of dynamic difficulty, are you planning on having the upper levels be harder in all dimensions, or having it split so the uppers are harder platforming but easier combat, whereas the lowers are harder combat but easier platforming?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9449752
The idea I'm following is that the upper levels are where all of the fancy stuff is going to be, and they're going to be more difficult all around but also be more plentiful and ammo and equipment. If you mess up too much and end up going through the "lower" route, there will be much more ammo and health starvation but less platforming and much easier combat. However I don't want the difference in difficulty to be night and day either, as both routes need to be valid ways to play the game.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9449764
For example, in the first level if you take the upper route you get a Plasma Gun for the next stage, however if you end up taking the lower route you don't get any Plasma Gun and the stage ends much faster. You also have fewer chances to find secrets in the lower route as all but one of them are in the upper route, meaning that more skilled and observant players will be more well equipped overall for the final level, whereas players who messed up too much will ultimately be punished for their lack of skill by being under equipped for future challenges.

Also, *they're going to be more difficult all around but also are more plentiful

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Why were most of the 8-bit palettes in classic shooters devoid of any cyan? Was it an attempt to differentiate themselves from Wolfenstein 3D which had the weird idiosyncrasy of making all metal cyan?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9447257
Grayscale amounts to 5-bit luminance, which is exactly what you get in 16bpp games. The other colors should be weighed based on matrix coefficients, so blue should only have 4 shades. For even better results, the gradients should be based on the PQ curve.

last_replies.com:

last_replies.com:
As a kid, the thought of being able to upgrade to a 7800 from the 2600 was the DREAM of every child. A dream we all soon forgot after the first of our skeptical parents bought their children an NES and Mario blew all our collective bras off.

In retrospect, I find its design uninspired. The 2600 was soulful, rugged with a taste of refinement. A lumberjack with a penchant for tea. The 7800 looks cheap, the silver strip a flimsy slap of foil wrapper, the plastic an identity crisis between streamlined and rounded, the rainbow stripe color scheme suggesting inclusion of all ideas but mastery of none.

In practice, you get as much as the compression allows for. I'm not sure how much that is with VQ, but you'd get close to 32-bit's worth of depth with just 8 bits using S3.
I'm talking theory, though. Voodoo is limited to 16-bit full stop. This is fine for the most part, except when you want to do lightmaps, which a lot of PC games did at full 24-bit precision.

ATI's hardware was apparently good with high bit-depth stuff. I wonder how that would fare for a console.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9449124
Hey, it's your money and the best time to start collecting is always now, seeing how the market doesn't look like it's going to crash any time soon and the supply of older consoles and games is just going to get smaller as things break and rare games go on and off the market.

In terms of how far $20,000 will get you, you'll definitely get all of your consoles, but your libraries will be somewhat thin. It really depends on what games you want, if you want boxes/manuals, and how long you're willing to hunt for.

Also, consider looking into importing from Japan if you want to save on the more expensive stuff. Obviously, import fees are a bitch, but a lot of games will be cheaper if you get the Japanese release even with that extra cost. You also have to be mindful of region locking and power conversion, but there are a lot of resources online for getting around that.

My reaction to this video. Followed by tears.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9447929
Not that anon but it usually goes down a chain from big businesses to small businesses. Big arcade chains like "Dave and Busters" will offer to sell their machines to smaller secondary arcade chains like "Chucke E Cheese". And then once CEC is done with the arcade machine, it might get sold to a smaller independently owned "Mom and Pop" arcade businesses. Places that aren't chains. When it gets sold it gets cheaper each time because it's used.

Until eventually the arcade machine is put up for sale on eBay or some other auction site...and if it doesn't get sold on auction then it might be eventually scrapped once it breaks. It depends on how long the final owner wants to keep it. That's how these arcades end up in private owners hands. Sometimes arcade owners have warehouse storage and just shove old arcades into their warehouse for many years.

Sometimes you can just walk into an arcade and ask if an older arcade game is for sale. It might be. It happens far more often than you think. It depends on the mood of the arcade business owner. But be prepared to spend several hundred dollars (for standard old arcade cabinets) to maybe $1K to $2K for old 1990s deluxe arcade machines (like an old deluxe Time Crisis machine or an old deluxe House of the Dead machine). It really depends on the condition of the machine. Do all the joysticks, buttons, and monitors work? How big is the machine is, and how much space does it takes up? If a machine is really banged up, then usually you can negotiate a cheaper price.

Really vintage stuff like "Pac Man" is really in demand and usually sells for a higher price to collectors. But again it depends on the owner. Do they want to hold onto the machine to get the best price possible, or do they want to get rid of it because it takes up too much space?

Last resort is stuff like this
>>9448190 happening. Really sad!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9448190
>>9448210
You might be able to salvage it, but those arcade machines are in pieces. It has been sitting outside for a while. Hmm...the frame might be good. If it hasn't rained, then the board and monitors might still work. You would have to buy new light guns though. Definitely A LOT of work to get those up and running again. And that's *if* the salvaged parts still work.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9448239
Well im glad to hear that, I was worried it just gets broken down into scrap.
Maybe Im just a sentimental old fart but it sucks to see arcade machines just wither and die like that, so many memories in those things.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9449369
>Well im glad to hear that, I was worried it just gets broken down into scrap.

Unfortunately, sometimes they do just break them down for scrap. It depends on the arcade. Sometimes the people don't want to deal with the extra hassle of selling it or auctioning the arcade machine off.

Personal story: I was trying to buy a machine from an arcade. I was saving up some funds, but when I returned to see if I could make a deal, the manager said they threw it out 2 weeks ago in the dumpster. It was long gone. I was deeply sad because I have yet to find another one.

To some arcade owners, they have zero sympathy or nostalgia for these machines. To them, the arcades are just "amusement machines" to be used and abused until they are no longer profitable and then tossed out our scrap. Zero love for them.

That's why despite a production run of 100,000 units being made for some popular arcade games, only a fraction of that amount remain today. Some places literally tossed them in the dumpster.

And 15 years later, these machines are in demand again. Let that be a lesson! Treat your arcade machines with care. You never know what the future holds.

There's probably a better thread on zeldix.net explaining it along with the MSU-MD/MD+ ones for Genesis. It's not the most interesting thing, but it would be better if the average user understood that the patch is the important part and that the audio files are generic and interchangeable. It would be interesting if every game just had the patch available and everyone just added whatever songs they felt like, but this doesn't tend to be their goal. They want to release both the patch AND be the ones to convert whatever generic audio files they can find floating around at the same time.
wav2msu - https://www.smwcentral.net/?p=section&a=details&id=4872
If you just used this on a random song and renamed the file to any position of something with the MSU1 patch, it'll play, and as long as the patch overwrites the correct position in any ROM hack, it'll also work. It takes relatively 5 seconds to do this per song. They really like giving the illusion that they're doing something that's too technically advanced for the average peasant to understand.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Yes, I too saw that LTT video.

How badly if at all would converting retro systems to use USB-C instead of their now decades old PSUs effect any sort of interference or image/audio quality? Or could it fry any other aftermarket modifications like ODEs or HDMI mods?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9446334
Yeah, Apple's chargers are expensive but they're actually reliable and better than most. The real problem is that no one shields anything anymore because the FCC doesn't care, so even good USB stuff is pretty noisy. It's also worth noting that if you mistakenly plug a USB-C PD charger into a console you've modded for USB-C, you could blow it up with 20V or something. Not everything is the same old 5V we've grown accustomed to from USB power anymore. That's why I like the dumb things I posted above, no mods needed (for me anyway, I mostly stick to 8-bit machines), they're easy to replace and if they die they can't spit out more than the 5V they're being fed.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9446350
>It's also worth noting that if you mistakenly plug a USB-C PD charger into a console you've modded for USB-C, you could blow it up with 20V or something.

Isn't that the whole reason that USB-PD requires circuity to regulate voltage otherwise it will only deliver the default 5V of USB power? That's why the USB-C console mods either make you use a cable that has the PD circuitry to deliver the right voltage or have that circuitry in the replacement power supply/adapter itself.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9447004
Yeah I'm just saying there's more to potentially go wrong, I would probably just use 5V supplies and call it a day, not like there's any shortage of them.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9446009
To add to the thread, you can see these boards use a switching regulator which can generate noise.
In fact the original PSUs do too because they are switch mode power supplies.
It's up to the downstream regulators and other circuitry on the mainboard to filter noise.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Right, I started this today and I have some thoughts

First and foremost being the original 2000 demo lighting and finisher mogs the finishied first level which ends like a limp dick
That aside, as I thought of the demo, this game is lightyears ahead of its time. Third person shooter on the face but it's actually a puzzle game that puts everyone's skillset to use through context hover, and lets you rapidly switch between the party by looking at them/right click menu or hotkey, quality example and what sold me on it was hacking a terminal with the jap, running a robot into a gas chamber attached to that terminal and then the repairman afrter the robot disabled the gas, all this with a right click then left click on relevant portrait, then switching back to the leader and turning too sharply and watching him climb a fence and plummet to his death (didn't game over), he just respawned at the regen checkpoint in embarrassment

Just so far it has remote control cars, levels that stretch out to a degree that the devs basically flaunt areas before they unleash the puzzles on you to get there, TPS combat and a plot straight our of Dredd
And I really need to mention the plot, for one, it starts on a dick joke (real meat? I'll show you real meat). And it's like if Dredd went wrong and they sent in a cleanup crew to see where their agents went, parallels with The Raid also work but the closest I've found to that experience in-game is ragdolling cunts with robot missiles

It's basically a perfect game and 75% off on GOG, do rec (just rename or delete the logos intro in the folder and it works beautifully on modern OS ((The chunky robot has a hard time registering context memes like doorknobs, personally I put that down to it being such a big bastard and trying smaller humans is an easier time, not sure if that was intended)
